docket_entries.description: ORDER. The status conference set for December 3, 2020, at 10:00 a.m., will be held by Zoom Webinar. Each party should designate a lead counsel to speak at the hearing by emailing the name of their lead counsel to Judge Donato's Courtroom Deputy, Ms. Lisa Clark, at jdcrd@cand.uscourts.gov by December 2, 2020, at 5:00 p.m. California time. The names for lead counsel are needed so that Ms. Clark can identify them during the Zoom hearing when the case is called. All lead counsel must call in fifteen minutes before the hearing to test internet, video, and audio capabilities. All counsel, parties, members of the public, and press may join the webinar using the link or information below: https://cand-uscourts.zoomgov.com/j/1617171523?pwd=VWJqM2ZYT1UvNFZ0ZHNZUUhGWTBCZz09 Webinar ID: 161 717 1523 Password: 213597 Or iPhone one-tap : US: +16692545252,,1617171523#,,1#,213597# or +16468287666,,1617171523#,,1#,213597# Or Telephone: Dial (for higher quality, dial a number based on your current location): US: +1 669 254 5252 or +1 646 828 7666PLEASE NOTE: Persons granted remote access to court proceedings are reminded of the general prohibition against photographing, recording, and rebroadcasting of court proceedings (including those held by telephone or videoconference). See General Order 58 at Paragraph III. Any recording of a court proceeding held by video or teleconference, including "screen-shots" or other visual copying of a hearing, is absolutely prohibited. Violation of these prohibitions may result in sanctions, including removal of court-issued media credentials, restricted entry to future hearings, or any other sanctions deemed necessary by the court. Please see https://www.cand.uscourts.gov/zoom for information on preparing for and participating in a Zoom Webinar. Signed by Judge James Donato on 12/2/2020. (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. There is no document associated with this entry.) (jdlc3S, COURT STAFF) (Filed on 12/2/2020) (Entered: 12/02/2020)

CLERK'S NOTICE VACATING SETTLEMENT CONFERENCE: The court has had multiple settlement conferences with the parties. The court had follow-up settlement conversations this week. The court vacates the settlement conference. It will hold any future settlement conference only if the parties can cometo the settlement conference prepared to resolve any differences. For example, if the plaintiffs need to do a site visit before addressing the medical claims, they must have that visit. The court reminds the parties that settlement agreements usually have enforcement mechanisms that are a more efficient and certain way of ensuring compliance than litigation. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler: Settlement Conference held on 5/14/2018.The court held a settlement conference with the parties and put an agreement in principle on the record. The parties agreed to the terms of the settlement and a process going forward to resolve the injunctive relief. The settlement put on the record today resolves the damages and injunction trial now set for June 25, 2018. The parties agreed that they would resolve the pending motions as follows. The plaintiff will withdraw the motion for class certification at ECF No. 85 without prejudice. The parties stipulate that the plaintiffs may file the proposed third amended complaint at ECF No. 89-1, which will terminate the motion at ECF No. 89 for leave to file that complaint and which will render moot the three motions to dismiss at ECF Nos. 78, 79, and 81. The parties agreed that the defendants' deadline to file motions to dismiss the third amended complaint will be extended until after the parties work through the injunctive relief components. The parties devised a process that includes the undersigned's assistance at a further mediation. The parties will update the court in a written submission during the week of July 2, 2018 and will propose a second in-person mediation at that time. The parties also will submit a stipulation to the trial judge memorializing their agreement that the settlement in principle moots the damages and injunction trial set for June 25 and their agreements regarding the pending motions. FTR Time: 5:15:36 - 5:35:42. Plaintiffs' Attorney: Yolanda Huang and Dennis Cunningham (with clients Andanna Ibe, Jaime Johnston, Annette Kozlowski, Mary Mapa, Rosa Perez, Denise Rorbacher, Tikisha Upshaw, Christina Zepeda, and Alexis Wah). Defendants' Attorneys: Gregory Thomas and Ope Peters (for Alameda County and the individual defendants with client representatives Assistant Sheriff Dennis Houghtelling, Commander Tom Madig, Captain Tara Russell, and claims adjuster Ken Maolini), Peter Bertling (for CMGC with client representative Ben Rice, General Counsel, and CFMG's insurance company representative Kathy Franks by telephone), and Thomas Rector (for Aramark with client representative Hal Yasa). (This is a text-only entry generated by the court. There is no document associated with this entry.) (Beeler, Laurel) (Date Filed: 5/14/2018) (Entered: 05/14/2018)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler: Settlement Conference held on 4/22/2019. The court held a further in-person settlement conference. The case settled (subject to the contingencies of approval) as to Aramark. For the rest of the case, the parties devised the following process. Subject to the approval of the County (and the court strongly recommends approval), the plaintiffs' counsel will conduct the two site visits discussed with Aramark and CFMG at Santa Rita. The parties will try to conduct those visits in two weeks, subject to everyone's schedule and the County's approval. Within 30 days, the plaintiffs' counsel will provide a pared-down list of remaining issues to the County, and the plaintiffs and CFMG will provide a joint update to the court about any disputes that remain between them. The County will respond in two weeks. The court set a further in-person settlement conference for Tuesday, June 18, 2019 at 10:00 a.m. for the remaining defendants (including appropriate client representatives, including Command staff conversant in the relevant issues regarding non-monetary relief). Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler: Settlement Conference held on 9/30/2019. The court held an in-person settlement conference and sets a further settlement conference for Friday, 11/22/2019 at 10:00 a.m. The parties will confer on the final written settlement agreement (after reviewing the audio recording and any transcript that the parties request) within two weeks and will update the court by 10/15/2019 by email to lbsettlement@cand.uscourts.gov and the court's personal email about their progress. Within that same time period, the County will provide the grievance forms for the past four months for blocks 21 and 24 (as discussed at the settlement conference), will circulate a written settlement proposal with the terms discussed, and will update the court by email (to the same addressees). During that time period, the plaintiffs will request from the County and CFMG any specific information about any specific incidents so that the County and CFMG may provide responsive reports. As to CFMG, the parties will arrange a site visit to take place after October 21, will schedule depositions of the two plaintiffs with individual damages claims (to take place after the next settlement conference, and presumably in December or January), and will update the court by email by 10/15/2019 about their progress. The court's expectation is that by November 15, 2019, the Aramark settlement will be finalized, and there will be one round of exchanges (at minimum) of written settlement proposals for the County and CFMG cases. The parties must lodge these proposals with the court no later than 11/15/2019 at 2 p.m. and may do so by email. Settlement Conference set for 11/22/2019 at 10:00 AM in San Francisco, Courtroom B, 15th Floor.Total Time in Court: 3 hours, 30 minutes. Not Reported. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler: Settlement Conference held on 2/27/2023. The court had a settlement conference. The non-monetary (Rule 23(b)) case against the County settled. The court worked out a process to finalize the non-monetary cases against Wellpath and Aramark as follows: (1) Wellpath will send policies and NHHC by next Monday, March 6, and the plaintiffs will respond back ten days later (including whether they want an in-person meeting with N.P. Possani, and (2) the plaintiffs will send a draft back to Aramark by next Monday, and Aramark will then reply with proposed menus. Given the pending class-certification motion, the court sets an overall time period of three weeks to resolve the non-monetary components. The non-monetary case will not resolve on a class basis and instead will resolve in the form of non-monetary relief. As to the damages cases for the individual plaintiffs, the case to the extent it involves food settled against the County and Aramark, subject to the contingency of finalizing the non-monetary piece. As to the damages case against the County, the County said that it would email the plaintiffs on February 27 with their summary of the claims against the County that remain. The parties will confer on Wednesday, March 1, and update the court. Assuming the County is correct, the court proposed a settlement number to resolve the County piece. If all of this works, then the only remaining claims will be the monetary claims against Wellpath, and the court will continue to work with the parties to resolve those. Total Time in Court: 4 hours, 34 minutes. Digital Recording Time: 3:56 - 4:04, matter transcribed by Peggy Schuerger of Ad Hoc Reporting. Plaintiffs' Attorney: Yolanda Huang. Also appearing: Plaintiffs Christine Zepeda and Jaclyn Mohrbacher.Defendants' Attorneys: Peter G. Bertling, Charles J. Reitmeyer, and Temitayo Peters. Also appearing: Chris Bowker via Zoom, Rick Huking, Jennifer Solopow, Lt. Tya Modeste, Lt. Leticia Davis, Captain April Luckett-Fahimi, Patricia Atkinson and Ken Maiolini and Ben Oram via Zoom. case_data.name: Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffs Office
case_data.plaintiff_description: Women prisoners, including pregnant women, at Alameda County Jail
case_data.summary:
On January 4, 2018, six women prisoners filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California alleging systematic, misogynistic mistreatment of women prisoners at the Alameda County Jail in Santa Rita, California. The plaintiffs sued Alameda County, the Alameda County Sheriff’s Office and California Forensic Medical Group (CFMG) under 42 U.S.C. §1983 for violations of their rights under the U.S. Constitution and state law. Represented by private counsel, they sought monetary, injunctive, and declaratory relief.

Specifically, the complaint alleges that pregnant women prisoners were denied medical attention and other accommodations including weather-appropriate clothing, nutritious food, feminine hygiene products, and fresh air. The specific conduct targeted toward pregnant women took place within an environment marked by general hostility toward women prisoners and indifference to women’s medical and hygienic needs. Further, the complaint alleged that the Alameda County Jail systematically discriminated against the women prisoners, compared to men prisoners, in access to reasonable facilities and services. In the complaint, the women prisoners sought recognition of class certification consisting of a main class of women prisoners with a sub-class of pregnant prisoners. The plaintiffs claimed that the conduct of the Alameda County Jail staff violated women prisoners’ rights protected by the First, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments to the Constitution.

On the same day that the initial complaint was filed, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a temporary restraining order to prevent further harm to the pregnant plaintiffs. The women prisoners also sought relief in the form of compensatory and punitive damages and attorneys’ fees for the litigation. The case proceeded before Judge James Donato.

On April 12, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint. The plaintiffs elaborated on the allegations in the original complaint of the mistreatment against pregnant women prisoners and discrimination against women prisoners in general. The second amended complaint also added additional causes of action under California state law. The second amended complaint delineated the named plaintiffs into various groups: current women prisoners, women who were formerly imprisoned, pregnant prisoners currently in custody, and formerly pregnant prisoners who suffered a miscarriage due to mistreatment while in custody. The complaint also identified additional named defendants beyond the Alameda County Sheriff’s Office and individuals employed therein, including the California Forensic Medical Group, retained to provide medical services to prisoners and Aramark Correctional Services, a for-profit food services provider at the Jail.

The amended complaint also amended the relief sought by the women prisoners. The plaintiffs requested that the court certify the plaintiff class of women prisoners and the subclass of pregnant women prisoners, and that the court issue emergency remedy, by decree, to ensure that the women prisoners receive the medical care and other accommodations they needed to be safe while in custody at the Alameda County Jail. Finally, in addition to the injunctive relief and compensatory and punitive damages requested in the original complaint, the plaintiffs requested that the court affirmatively direct the defendants to fully comply with all state statutes and regulations regarding medical treatment, nutrition, activities, and personal hygiene for women prisoners.

On December 31, 2018, one named plaintiff moved to relate the case to Upshaw v. County of Alameda. The parties began engaging in settlement negotiations and entered an agreement in principle on May 14, 2018. Settlement proceedings were heard by Magistrate Judge Laurel Beeler. The parties initially agreed to resolve money damages and other substantive relief and the plaintiffs agreed to withdraw the motion for class certification. The parties held a number of settlement conferences between May 14, 2018 and December 12, 2019.

A named plaintiff moved to relate the case to Gonzalez v. Ahern on May 7, 2019. Though opposed by the defendants, on May 15, 2020, the court related this case to Gonzalez v. Ahern. For further information, refer to the Clearinghouse page, available at this link.

On November 17, 2020, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction. They filed a fourth amended complaint on April 6, 2021, adding Well-Path Management as a party to the case as a successor of CFMG. The complaint also added Aramark Correctional Services as a defendant, a private contractor who contracted with the County to operate kitchens at Santa Rita Jail. The defendants filed motions to dismiss the fourth amended complaint between April 20-30, 2021. While the motions remained pending before the court, a settlement conference was held on April 4, 2022, in which the parties were unable to reach a settlement.

From September 30, 2022, to October 3, 2022, the defendants filed various motions for summary judgment. Prior to a hearing on the summary judgment motions, the court held another settlement conference on February 27, 2023. Following the conference, the non-monetary claims against the County were settled in a private settlement agreement. The court also implemented a process for settling the non-monetary claims against Aramark and Well-Path, and proposed a monetary amount for the damages claims against the County. The monetary claims against Well-Path remained pending, the parties having been unable to reach an agreement on an amount. On April 4, 2023, the monetary claims against the County, as well as the monetary and non-monetary claims against Aramark, were settled in full in a private settlement agreement. Both the monetary and non-monetary claims against Well-Path were unable to settle. The court vacated a scheduled settlement conference, stating that the court had exhausted its ability to help. 

As of December 2023, the trial remained pending, and litigation remains ongoing.

05/14/2018  100   Minute Entry for proceedings held before Magistrate Judge 
Laurel Beeler: Settlement Conference held on 5/14/2018. 
The court held a settlement conference with the parties and 
put an agreement in principle on the record. The parties 
agreed to the terms of the settlement and a process going 
forward to resolve the injunctive relief. The settlement put on 
the record today resolves the damages and injunction trial now 
set for June 25, 2018. The parties agreed that they would 
resolve the pending motions as follows. The plaintiff will 
withdraw the motion for class certification at ECF No. 85 
without prejudice. The parties stipulate that the plaintiffs may 
file the proposed third amended complaint at ECF No. 89-1, 
which will terminate the motion at ECF No. 89 for leave to file 
that complaint and which will render moot the three motions 
to dismiss at ECF Nos. 78, 79, and 81. The parties agreed that 
the defendants' deadline to file motions to dismiss the third 
amended complaint will be extended until after the parties 
work through the injunctive relief components. The parties 
devised a process that includes the undersigned's assistance at 
a further mediation. The parties will update the court in a 
written submission during the week of July 2, 2018 and will 
propose a second in-person mediation at that time. The parties 
also will submit a stipulation to the trial judge memorializing 

their agreement that the settlement in principle moots the 
damages and injunction trial set for June 25 and their 
agreements regarding the pending motions. 
FTR Time: 5:15:36 - 5:35:42.

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 164   Filed 05/15/20   Page 1 of 2
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
 
RELATED CASE ORDER 
 
 
A Motion for Administrative Relief to Consider Whether Cases Should be Related or a Sua Sponte 
Judicial Referral for Purpose of Determining Relationship (Civil L.R. 3-12) has been filed.  The time for 
filing an opposition or statement of support has passed.  As the judge assigned to case   
 
18-cv-00050-JD     Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffs Office 
 
I find that the more recently filed case(s) that I have initialed below are related to the case 
assigned to me, and such case(s) shall be reassigned to me.  Any cases listed below that are not related to 
the case assigned to me are referred to the judge assigned to the next-earliest filed case for a related 
case determination. 
 
 
Case  Title  Related  Not Related 
19-cv-07423-JSC  Gonzalez v. Ahern    X 
 
ORDER 
 
The parties are instructed that all future filings in any reassigned case are to bear the initials of 
the newly assigned judge immediately after the case number. Any case management conference in any 
reassigned case will be rescheduled by the Court.  The parties shall adjust the dates for the conference, 
disclosures and report required by FRCivP 16 and 26 accordingly. Unless otherwise ordered, any dates for 
hearing noticed motions are vacated and must be re- noticed by the moving party before the newly 
assigned judge; any deadlines set by the ADR Local Rules remain in effect; and any deadlines established 
in a case management order continue to govern, except dates for appearance in court, which will be 
rescheduled by the newly assigned judge. 
 
 
1 

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 164   Filed 05/15/20   Page 2 of 2
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
 
CLERKโS NOTICE 
 
 
The court has reviewed the motion and determined that no cases are related and no 
reassignments shall occur. 
 
 
Dated:  May 15, 2020  By:    
       Lisa Clark, Deputy Clerk 
 
2

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 1   Filed 01/04/18   Page 1 of 18
 
LAW OFFICES OF YOLANDA HUANG 
1 
YOLANDA HUANG, SBN 104543

Attorneys for Plaintiffs 
9   
 
10  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
11  FOR THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
12   
JACLYN MOHRBACHER, ERIN ELLIS,        
13 
   
DOMINIQUE JACKSON, CHRISTINA 
   No. 18-cv- 
14  ZEPEDA, ALEXIS WAH, AND KELSEY 
 
ERWIN, on behalf of themselves and others 
15   
similarly situated,  
COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
 
16 
    Plaintiffs,  AND DAMAGES 
 
17 
  vs. 
(Civil Rights) 
18   
 
Demand for Jury Trial 
ALAMEDA COUNTY SHERIFFโS OFFICE, 
19 
 
GREGORY J. AHERN, BRETT M. KETELES, 
20  TOM MADIGAN, D. SKOLDQVIST,  LT. 
HATTAWAY, SGT. CALAGARI (sp), 
21 
DEPUTY DIVINE  (512), DEPUTY DEBRA 
FARMANIAN, DEPUTY WEATHERBEE 
22 
(238),  DEPUTY TANIA POPE, DEPUTY 
23  WINSTEAD, DEPUTY CAINE,  ALAMEDA 
COUNTY and DOES 1 thru 50. 
24 
 
25                                Defendants.                                                                                                                                                                                                                              
                 
26 
  Plaintiffs JACLYN MOHRBACHER, ERIN ELLIS, DOMINIQUE JACKSON, CHRISTINA 
27  ZEPEDA, ALEXIS WAHL, and KELSEY ERWIN, on behalf of themselves and others similarly 
28  situated, allege as follows:   
 
Page 1 of 18 
Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffโs Office.     
  
 

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 1   Filed 01/04/18   Page 2 of 18
 
INTRODUCTION 
1 
1. This case arises from a strong and highly reprehensible pattern and practice of aggressively 
2 
misogynist, apparently programmatic, maltreatment of women prisonersโso severe as to 
3 
have resulted in two recent miscarriages, and a third woman giving birth, alone and 
4 
unattended, in a solitary confinement cellโat the Alameda County jail at Santa Rita, 
5 
California.  Several of the named plaintiffs (including those three) complain of specific, 
6 
purposeful and aggravated violations of the First, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, Thirteenth and 
7  Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution, and parallel provisions of the California 
8  Constitution, detailed within, resulting in serious injury and deprivation under federal and 
9  state civil rights laws.   
2. At any given time, Alameda County has approximately 250 women prisoners under its custody 
10 
and control.  On information and belief, plaintiffs allege that of these 250 women prisoners, at 
11 
any given moment, approximately 10 are pregnant, and that over 2500 women with 150 of 
12 
whom are pregnant, cycle through Santa Rita Jail in a year.  
13 
3. Plaintiffs Jaclyn Mohrbacher, Erin Ellis, Dominique Jackson, are three pregnant, female 
14 
prisoners, currently incarcerated in Santa Rita Jail, who urgently seek emergency relief 
15 
against defendants because they are pregnant, two of them four or five months pregnant and 
16 
experiencing frequent โspottingโ and bleeding from their vaginas, but have been repeatedly 
17  abused by being held in isolation cells, kept outdoors without sufficient warm clothing, and 
18  subjected to repeated accusations of drug abuse and strip searched.  In concert with this abuse, 
19  plaintiffs and proposed class members are denied medical attention, denied required 
medication and all other needed accommodation โincluding warm clothing, blankets, healthy 
20 
nutritious and sufficient food, fresh air, etcโby defendant staff members.  Instead, defendants 
21 
have repeatedly demanded that plaintiffs agree to have an abortion, accused said plaintiffs of 
22 
being a drug addict, and refused all other recognition and assistance for each plaintiffโs 
23 
delicate condition.  Other pregnant womenโincluding those who miscarriedโhave similarly 
24 
been scorned, branded and mistreated in the jail in recent timesโto a further, under a regime 
25 
marked by intense general hostility to women prisoners, and studied indifference to their 
26 
serious medical and hygienic needs. 
27  4. .   In addition, all named plaintiffs herein, including the three mentioned above and others 
28  whose injuries and deprivations at the hands of defendants do not involve pregnancyโbut 
 
Page 2 of 18 
Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffโs Office.     
  
 

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 1   Filed 01/04/18   Page 3 of 18
 
very often do involve nasty and hostile refusals to acknowledge or respond to feminine 
1 
hygienic needsโcomplain of extensive, systematic discrimination against the women 
2 
prisoners at Santa Rita, compared to the men, in all aspects of life in the jail: food, access to 
3 
clean clothes, fresh air and out-of-cell  jobs, education, exercise and activities, counseling, 
4 
phone calls, family visits, and more.   
5 
5.   These women also seek injunctive relief, under the First, Fourth, Fifth and Fourteenth 
6 
Amendments requiring a total cessation of inhumane and sexually biased treatment and forms 
7  of treatment of women prisoners by defendants, and effective, outside monitoringโon behalf 
8  of themselves and all others similarly situated, namely all women prisoners currently held or 
9  to be held in the future at the Santa Rita Jail, as a Class, per Rule 23, F.R. Civ P.; full 
compliance with 15 CCR 3355.2 including appropriately implemented, individualized, plan of 
10 
care for all pregnant women to enable pregnant prisoners who desire to do so,  to carry their 
11 
babies to term and deliver healthy babies; that the unequal treatment of women prisoners 
12 
cease; and, for the immediate implementation of the requirements of California statute 
13 
including Penal Code ยง3409 on the care and treatment of women prisoners. 
14 
6.   Within then, will be found the individual claims of the named plaintiffs, for equitable relief, 
15 
and damagesโ together with a prayer for injunctive relief for the Class of women prisoners, 
16 
and statements of the facts underlying the various claims and allegations.  As will be seen, 
17  plaintiffs have named as defendants the Alameda County Sheriff, Gregory Ahern; Assistant 
18  Sheriff for Detention and Corrections, Brett Keteles, Commander for Detention and 
19  Corrections, Tom Madigan and Watch Commander for Santa Rita Jail, Capt. D. Skoldqvist 
along with a large number of officers and deputies, who are guards and other staff members at 
20 
Santa Rita Jail, who have been involved in the various tyrannies against women prisoners 
21 
complained of herein, and will or would be subject to the injunction(s) sought hereinโand 
22 
who, depending on the Courtโs outlook, may be more readily dealt with herein as a defendant 
23 
Class.   
24 
7.   Also named are the Sheriffโs Department and the County itself, in respondeat with respect to 
25 
the State Law claims herein; and also for their unconstitutional explicit and de facto polic(ies)

TO THE COURT, ALL DEFENDANTS AND THEIR COUNSELS OF RECORD: 
 
1 
PLAINTIFFSโ PROPOSAL TO TERMINATE MEDIATION AND CONSOLIDATE CASES

PLEASE TAKE NOTICE: 
1 
Pursuant to the Courtโs invitation on 2/28/19, plaintiffs by counsel โhereby propose to 
2 
end the mediation process, after a year with no results, and come back in front of the Court.  Then, 
3 
with its leave, we would ask the Court to consolidate the UPSHAW et al. vs. ALAMEDA 
4 
COUNTY, et al. 3:18-cv-07814-JD (herein after the โSleep caseโ) with the main case 
5 
MOHRBACHER, ET AL. V. ALAMEDA COUNTY  SHERIFFโS OFFICE, et al. 3:18-cv-00050-JD, 
6 
(hereinafter the โMain caseโ), and give us 20-30 days to submit an amended, omnibus complaint, 
7  charging systemic, endemic, categorically  unconstitutional maltreatment of women at Santa Rita 
8  Jailโespecially including pregnant women, and in violation of rights of those unbornโ
9  encompassing all the particulars of apparent ongoing constitutional wrongdoing, under both 8th 
and 14th Amendments, including other emergent claims, which we have detected in a year of 
10 
detailed communications with women in and out of Santa Rita.1 
11 
We will be seeking intervention by the Court in the form of specific directions for reform, 
12 
and change, prohibitions on various wrong actions, and setting standards, all based on findings 
13 
across a broad front of particular claims.  
14 
A working but unrefined outline of these Claims or categories of claims, could be as 
15 
follows: 
16 
1.  Constantly Bad, Insufficient, non-nourishing Food (especially for pregnant women); 
17  after earnest promises; for example live, wriggling maggots in the beans, one night about  two  
18  weeks ago, on five trays randomly chosen by the deputy.2 
19  2.  Bad Medical Care; poorly trained, incompetent, careless, indifferent personnel, and 
defective equipment; poor and dangerously inaccurate record-keeping and medicine scans; 
20 
wretched mistreatment of women in drug withdrawal; and more; the onerous $3.00 fee to submit, 
21 
simply submit, a request to see a medical person remains, despite defendantsโ promise way last 
22 
Spring, and menstrual pads are still in constant short supply, etc; 
23 
                                                                    
24 
1    This has been mainly accomplished and recorded by our invaluable Investigator, Carey 
25  Lamprecht, a certified paralegal, who is a true and accurate repository and source of good 
information about daily life and events in the Womenโs section of Santa Rita Jail from early Spring, 
26 
2018 to now.  Such investigation necessitated by the lack and failure of defendants to provide 
accurate data and information about the workings of the  jail. 
27 
2 This shocking episode is recounted for its shock value, without a doubt; because it illustrates the 
28  degree of abandon, and, objectively, wantonness, as it were, with which the women are treated in this 
jail. 
 
2 
PLAINTIFFSโ PROPOSAL TO TERMINATE MEDIATION AND CONSOLIDATE CASES 
Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffโs Office ,United States District Court, Northern District of California, Case No. 3:18-cv-00050 JD 
  
 

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 133   Filed 03/14/19   Page 3 of 8
 
3.  A Corrupted, disrupted grievance process, wherein forms are withheld or disappeared 
1 
by hostile deputies after submission, and complaints which do make it through are invariably 
2 
whitewashed, and offending deputies never held accountable;  
3 
4.  A Corrupted disciplinary process; frequent illicit group punishments, etc, and no clear 
4 
written rules, but mostly made-up on the spot, ongoing denial of (useless) handbooks, random 
5 
summary punishment by unreasonable and humiliating strip and โsquat and coughโ searches, and 
6 
undue denial of yard, classes and mail; more; 
7    5. Maladministration in so many ways: prolonged, unjustified, punitive confinement to cells; 
8  the limited โPODโ (outโofโcell) time then often scheduled at 6:00 am, then cut off early; access to 
9  phones limited to these early hour POD times when lawyers, etc. cannot be reached, 3 a.m. pill call 
and much-too-early wake-up times (as we saw); reclassification as punishment; great over-use of 
10 
shackling; a gross ITR room where women must wait hours for โprocessingโ when returning from 
11 
Court, and pregnant ones get no priority, etc, etc, etc.  Women required to maintain cell cleanliness 
12 
but provided only Cleaning times and supplies have not improved, etc, etc.  These defendants are 
13 
deep dug in;  
14 
  6.  Failure to properly screen, train, supervise and discipline line officers to counter and block 
15 
abusive tendencies; indulgence of misconduct, and โmean deputiesโ whose tyranniesโin what has 
16 
been called an โoperational disconnectโ, whereby the commanders have no โsituational awarenessโ of 
17  how officers on the line behaving---and other warning signs are ignored.  The mean deputies are at 
18  the heart of the problem here, along with obtuse, prejudiced administrative policy & practice.  
19  Examples are replete including the regular discard of the few, but important personal possession these 
women have, including family photos, cards from children, and in one instance, a womanโs ring, the 
20 
last memento from her deceased father; 
21 
  7. Unspoken Policy of constant, deliberate, unjustifiably punitive and abusive infliction of 
22 
fear, guilt, shaming, discomfort, neglect, misery and suffering, all unjustified, and gratuitous and 
23 
laced with malice, by officers in charge of daily life; and, 
24 
  8.  An ongoing factual dispute wherein defendants deny these wrongdoings, particularly 
25 
claims that guards are mean and nasty with repeated assertions that the guards have families and love 
26 
their children, to which plaintiffs respond with the research and findings of Phillip Zimbardo, author 
27 
28 
 
3 
PLAINTIFFSโ PROPOSAL TO TERMINATE MEDIATION AND CONSOLIDATE CASES 
Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffโs Office ,United States District Court, Northern District of California, Case No. 3:18-cv-00050 JD 
  
 

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 133   Filed 03/14/19   Page 4 of 8
 
and master of the Stanford Prison Experiment who documented that โ[t]here were no bad apples in 
1 
the barrel, it was the barrel itself that created evil.โ 3  
2 
  Further, we ask the Court: 
3 
1.  To make specific orders for Defendants to halt the night time sleep disruption at Santa 
4 
Rita Jail; 
5 
  We will be asking the Court: 
6 
2.  To consider making specific orders, after hearings, on acute specific problems (such as 
7  spoiled food, inadequate nutrition for pregnant women); or  in the alternative, 
8  3.  To consider initiating specific inquiries with an eye to developing both a record of 
9  things that have happened, and evidence of the violations alleged, and disposition of 
specific issues; and, 
10 
4.  Class Certification - to make short work of the decision to certify the class of these 
11 
women, booked into SRJ (and out, for some relevant period after), and a subclass of 
12 
those who are pregnantโwhere we will also be asserting a second sub-class, of 
13 
addicted women, who go into withdrawal in custody, and are all too often treated 
14 
punitively and inadequately, and with callous and deliberate indifference, if not 
15 
outright cruelty under an 8th Amendment standard. 
16 
5.  To make specific provisions for ample, effective access to the Women for counselโ
17  well beyond the current apparently baseless restrictions on access which defendants 
18  enforce 4, let alone the types of harassment, resistance, and delay we meet so oftenโto 
19  and including prohibiting counsels from meeting with more than one prisoner at a 
time.  The bar on group meetings denies opportunities for the women to discuss, 
20 
understand and reach agreement(s) about the case, and for development of live, 
21 
current evidence of the ongoing tyrannies plaintiffs suffer under as complained of 
22 
herein.   
23 
6.   
24 
25 
26                                                                      
3 Zimbardo, Philip G. Open Forum, 05/17/2004, Attached as Exhibit A. 
27 
4 Each housing unit in Santa Rita Jail has only one (1) attorney interview room. which quickly fill up. 
28  Further SRJ limits attorney visits to 56 hours permitted out of 168 hours in a week, and of those 56 
hours, only 28 fall within tradition work times.    
 
4 
PLAINTIFFSโ PROPOSAL TO TERMINATE MEDIATION AND CONSOLIDATE CASES

  In Conclusion, we believe there is good law on the issues and facts at hand.   We look forward 
1 
to digging in on all these issues.

Page 1 of 18 
Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffโs Office. First Amended Complaint     
  
 

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 18   Filed 02/01/18   Page 2 of 18
 
  Plaintiffs JACLYN MOHRBACHER, ERIN ELLIS, and DOMINIQUE JACKSON, now 
1 
joined by others named within, on behalf of themselves and those they speak for and seek to 
2 
represent herein---along with those others now named and to be named individually as plaintiffs---for 
3 
themselves and others, pursuant to the Courtโs discussion with Counsel at the status call on January 8, 
4 
2018, and as of right per R.15(a) F.R.Civ P, now submit this amended version (FAC) of their 
5 
previously filed Complaint, as follows: 
6 
I. INTRODUCTION 
7 
1.  Plaintiffs have alleged a strong and reprehensible, and unconstitutional pattern and practice of 
8  aggressively misogynist, apparently programmatic, maltreatment of women prisoners, and pregnant 
9  women in particularโso severe as to have resulted inter alia in at least three recent miscarriages, and 
10  another woman giving birth after screaming in labor pain all night, while alone and unattended in a 
solitary confinement cellโat the Alameda County jail at Santa Rita, California.  The named 
11 
individual plaintiffs describe and complain of specific, purposeful, aggravated violations of the First, 
12 
Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, Thirteenth and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution, and parallel 
13 
provisions of the California Constitution, along with flagrant violations of statute and official 
14 
regulations, all detailed within, resulting in serious injury and deprivation under federal and state civil 
15 
rights laws for which various individuals seek damages herein.  
16 
2.  More to the point, the representative plaintiffs have alleged that the Sub-class of pregnant 
17 
prisoners, and each of them, are strongly threatened with irreparable harm---and have no adequate 
18 
remedy at Law for it, obviously---resulting from grossly inadequate nourishment, warmth, sanitation 
19  medical care and other necessities of pregnancy, unless this honorable Court will intervene in a 
20  strong and comprehensive way, either by causing the Sheriffโs Department to hold or assign women 
prisoners who are pregnant in some place besides the Jail, or making a preliminary and permanent 
21 
decree, with prohibitions and remedial directions, and follow through to ensure compliance.  
22 
Defendantsโ maltreatment and abuse of prisoners who are pregnant involves apparently willful 
23 
violations of existing jail policies and procedures, and California statutes and Regulations, as well as 
24 
fundamental constitutional principles.  Despite repeated complaints and even prior lawsuits, 
25 
defendants have repeatedly failed to follow policies, statutes and regulations, even after being 
26 
notified of resulting injuries and harms.   
27 
3.  Described within, the plaintiffsโ evidence shows callous, deliberate and systematic disregard for 
28 
the safety, health and wellbeing of pregnant women prisoners in defendantsโ custody and control, and 
 
Page 2 of 18 
Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffโs Office. First Amended Complaint     
  
 

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 18   Filed 02/01/18   Page 3 of 18
 
their unborn children---whose interests surely deserve independent protection---and the Court must 
1 
put a stop to it.  At a minimum, every pregnant prisoner must be provided with an individualized, 
2 
appropriate and implemented plan of care---as required by statute and regulation!---which will 
3 
genuinely assist and enable those who desire it to carry their babies to term and deliver healthy 
4 
babies, 
5 
4.  New Defendant(s).   As we learned at the hearing, the Sheriff and the County defendants 
6 
broadly deny any responsibility for care of pregnant prisoners, and assert that their contract medical 
7  provider, the California Forensic Medical Group (โCFMGโ), a for-profit corporate enterprise, is 
8  wholly responsible for all aspects of the care and treatment of pregnant women prisoners; and they 
9  insist CFMG is an indispensible party, at least.  Plaintiffs reject any notion that blame is to be shifted 
here, but are glad to include these others who apparently share it, or some of it.  The proper care of 
10 
pregnant women clearly goes beyond provision of adequate medical attention. 
11 
5.  Accordingly, plaintiffs do hereby add as defendants and complain against the 
12 
CALIFORNIA FORENSIC MEDICAL GROUP (CFMG), a corporation, and its MANAGERS 
13 
and EMPLOYEES assigned to Santa Rita, as jointly and severally liable with the County and 
14 
Sheriffโs Department defendants to the plaintiffs and the pregnant Subclass in particular, for 
15 
the injuries and deprivations, caused and being caused, and the ongoing urgent default in, and legal 
16 
and constitutional inadequacies of, and urgent remedial needs regarding reform of, the care and 
17  custody of pregnant women held at Santa Rita, all as complained of herein. 
18  6.  Plaintiffs also hereby add Captain T. RUSSELL who is a captain within the command chain of 
19  Santa Rita Jail and the Alameda County Sheriffโs Office. 
 
20 
**     **      **      ** 
21 
7.  Beyond the urgent issues involving pregnancy, the plaintiffs herein (in their final grouping), on 
22 
behalf of themselves and all women prisoners at Santa Ritaโwhose injuries and deprivations at the 
23 
hands of defendants do not involve pregnancy, but very often do involve nasty and hostile refusals to 
24 
acknowledge or respond to feminine hygienic needsโnow also again complain as a Class, as 
25 
described and asserted within, of extensive, systematic discrimination against the women prisoners at 
26 
Santa Rita, compared to the men.  Invidious treatment of women occurs in all aspects of life in the 
27  jail: jobs, food, access to bathrooms, showers, hygiene, clean clothes, fresh air and out-of-cell time, 
28  education classes and activities, counseling, phone calls, family visits, and more.  These women also 
 
Page 3 of 18 
Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffโs Office. First Amended Complaint     
  
 

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 18   Filed 02/01/18   Page 4 of 18
 
seek injunctive relief, under the First, Fourth, Fifth and Fourteenth Amendments per R.65 F.R.Civ P., 
1 
and the Bane Act (Cal Civil Code #52.1)โrequiring a total cessation of inhumane and sexually and 
2 
gender-biased unequal treatment and forms of treatment of women prisoners by defendants, and 
3 
providing effective, outside monitoringโon behalf of themselves and others similarly situated, 
4 
namely women prisoners currently held or to be held in the future at the Santa Rita Jail, as a 
5 
Class, per Rule 23, F.R.Civ P.  Plaintiffs likewise seek full compliance with 15 CCR 3355.2; and 
6 
implementation of California Penal Code ยง3409, on the proper care and treatment of women 
7  prisoners. 
8  i.  **    **    **    ** 
9  8.  This First Amended Complaint thus adds additional named plaintiffs, listed below;  adds 
medical provider CFMG and its involved personnel as defendants, and re-presents the equitable 
10 
claims of the pregnant Sub-class, the larger discrimination claims by the broad class, and the 
11 
individual claims at Law of named plaintiffs and class membersโincluding money damages for the 
12 
Estates and the mothers of stillborn children, as well as for the sadistic denial of bathroom use, 
13 
withholding of feminine hygiene materials, and other physical depredations and specific deprivations 
14 
of right that have been reportedโwith a framework for adding others who may be encountered as 
15

predominate here over individual concerns, so certification is also proper under Section (b)(3).

tanto at the very least, or otherwise separately from the main class alleged herein, so that the

27 
by Both Groups of defendants, as shown and to be shown herein reflects and includes violation of

those women plaintiffsโ Fourteenth Amendment rights to Due Process of Law---in the form of decent

I.  PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
16 
1.  This Second Amended Complaint is submitted in response to the Courtโs recognition 
17 
that the case evolved, while the Motion demanding emergency intervention was pending, as 
18 
plaintiffsโ ongoing investigation of maltreatment endured by pregnant women in Santa Rita has 
19 
revealed a broadly degraded, oppressive regime in the jail, which violates the rights of all the women 
20 
held there in substantial, concrete, injurious ways; the harmfulness of which to pregnant women and 
21 
their babies is obviously then magnified, intolerably. 
22  2.  Pregnant Women Prisoners at Santa Rita are held in conditions, and (mis)treated by its 
23  custody and medical staff, in ways which are wrongful, and oppressive, wholly unjustified by any 
24  legitimate jail purposeโindeed counterproductive to all good faith custody practiceโand harmful, 
injurious and threatening to the womenโs health and well-being and that of their unborn children, all 
25 
to a degree which violates their fundamental rights under the Constitutions of the United States, and 
26 
California, and also fails to satisfy statutory and regulatory standards and requirements, and indeed 
27 
the jailโs own policies.   
28 
3.  Sheriffโs Department practices and attitudes towards women prisoners and their needs

and wants, regarding medical problems, feminine hygiene, sanitation (and rodent infestation), 
1

2 
discipline and illicit punishment, stultified grievance practice, and all the other hot and cold 
3 
interpersonal aspects between the keepers and the kept, in the myriad processes of jail lifeโproduce 
4 
a group living environment which is loud, mean, chaotic, remorseless, endlessly stressful and unsafe 
5 
in all ways.  Pregnant prisoners suffer from a poor, meager and often unwholesome diet, which leaves 
6 
themโall of themโconstantly hungry. There is a near-complete lack of regular exercise, and proper 
7  rest, and, truly, basic respect for their singular medical and other needs.  Except for being offered 
8  abortion, sometimes quite urgently; and sometimes, randomly being taken to the hospital for check-
9  up, they basically get no help, no information, no counseling, no nothing.   
4.  That is to say that daily life in Santa Rita is toxic and dangerous to a pregnant woman 
10 
without a doubt; and even more so to her baby, that is elementary.  Plaintiffs mean to assert fully the 
11 
material rights of each unborn child affected hereinโincluding those where the life was lost under 
12 
defendantsโ mindless tyranniesโand all other cases found lurking and festering in these dismal 
13

14 
report this week of March 26 that a woman prisoner gave birth during her current incarceration and 
15 
the baby was immediately taken from her and has not been returned.  Several days later this new 
16 
mother has been denied any opportunity even to touch her new baby โlet alone hold it, feed it, 
17  comfort it and comfort and console herself in the warmth of the miracle of its whole birth.  It is 
18  beyond any expression of outrage that defendants would employ or associate with anyone with the 
19  deep cruelty, sadism, and perversity of mind and soul that would be required to carry out such a 
monstrous act, because the mother is a prisoner.  That the pretense will be that โsecurityโ or some 
20 
other supposed rule required it only makes the story more sickening. 
21 
5.  Even in the limited amount of investigation we have managed to accomplish since the 
22 
inception of the case, it is beyond clear, and patent, that the county jail environment is radically 
23 
unsuitable, deleterious, and gravely threatening and dangerous to expectant mothers; and that the 
24 
situation cannot be truly remedied without establishment of calm, appropriate, separate quarters for 
25 
their confinement.  The obvious, fundamental rights, and above all the minimum physical and health 
26 
needs of the altogether blameless babies in wombsโgiven the inevitably harsh and unforgiving 
27  nature of county jail life, as shown herein and to be shown; and, more crucially here, the relentless 
28  antagonism and heartless nastiness so frequently shown to women prisoners by so many staff

en masse.

grouping), on behalf of themselves and all women prisoners at Santa Ritaโwhose injuries and

Sheriffโs Department individually, along with a number of John and Jane Does who are guards and

to the injunctional orders, directions and prohibitions sought herein, as co-defendants;

28  respondeat with respect to the State Law claims herein; and also for their unconstitutional explicit

and de facto polic(ies) of discrimination and systematic maltreatmentโparticularly of pregnant and

15.  Plaintiffs name ARAMARK Correctional Services, L.L.C.โand JOHN & JANE

ROEs Nos. 51-100, their involved cooperators and employeesโas co-defendants; where, in truth,

they are third party defendants vis-a-vis the defendant Sheriff et al, who plaintiffs continue to charge

13 
15.  The Jurisdiction of this honorable Court derives from the provisions of the First, 
14 
Fourth, Fifth, Thirteenth and Fourteenth Amendments to the United State Constitution, by way of the 
15 
Civil Rights Acts, 42 U.S.C. ยงยง1981 (as to certain plaintiffs), 1983 et seq. and 1988;  28 U.S.C.

19  Intradistrict Assignment 
20  16.  The claims alleged herein arose in the County of Alameda, State of California. 
Therefore, venue and assignment, under 28 U.S.C. ยง 1391(b), lies in the United States District Court

for the Northern District of California, San Francisco Division or Oakland Division.

and regulation of defendant CFMG.  The conditions in the infirmary are often even harsher as 
25 
pregnant women are denied beds and forced to sleep on a thin pad on the floor, and the rooms are 
26 
kept dark so that the only light comes in from the glass in the doorway, so dark that it is not even 
27  possible to read or pick out mouse fecal matter served in meal trays. 
28  52.  In sum, from the accounts of these women, and more who continue to connect and add 
 
Page 16 of 24 
Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffโs Office. Second Amended Complaint, Case No. 3:18-cv-00050-JD 
 

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 72   Filed 04/12/18   Page 17 of 24
 
their voices---and notwithstanding disclaimers by the County defendants, or CFMG defendants 
1 
hiding behind obscure provisions of a contract---it is clear there are gross deficiencies in the 
2 
accommodation of pregnant women prisoners at Santa Rita, which have caused and continue to cause 
3 
great injury to numerous women (e.g., the wrongful death of stillborn children), and deprivation of 
4 
fundamental rights in the form of widespread, indeed systemic Deliberate Indifference to Serious 
5 
Medical Needs these women obviously have, and gross denial of Due Process, especially for the 
6 
unborn, and will go on causing and risking such injuries, losses and deprivations if nothing is done. 
7  B.   Discrimination Against Women in General 
8  53.   Furthermore, Defendantsโ abuse and mistreatment of women prisoners is part and 
9  parcel of the discrimination and unequal treatment meted out to women prisoners as compared to 
male prisoners.  Women prisoners are denied the educational classes and opportunities available to 
10 
male prisoners; denied the access to outdoor (fresh air) or yard time and yard space available to male 
11 
prisoners.  Defendants impose greater repression and restrictions, including being prohibited from 
12 
talking during meals, so that one prisoner cannot offer extra unwanted food to another, or one cannot 
13 
ask for anotherโs unwanted food.  Women prisoners cannot exchange information nor share support 
14 
regarding defendantsโ programmatic abuse during the one period of time they are together.  Women 
15 
prisoners have greater restrictions than male prisoners, including being told where to sit during meals.  
16 
Women prisoners are strip searched and subjected to body cavity searches for little or no good 
17  reason---except to maintain domination---with greater frequency and regularity than male prisoners.  
18  54.  Grievance Procedures.  In order to commence grievance procedures, prisoners are 
19  required to request a grievance form from a Sheriffโs deputy.  The Sheriffโs deputy, per defendant 
Sheriffโs policy 16.03 โshallโ provide the prisoner with a grievance form.  However, these deputies 
20 
frequently fail or refuse to provide the grievance forms, either informing the women prisoner that she 
21 
should not grieve the issue, that the issue is not grievable, or to simply grossly delay and then fail to 
22 
provide the forms requested.  While the procedure prescribes that the prisoner is provided a pink 
23 
carbon of the completed form with a grievance number, at times the pink carbon is not provided to 
24 
the prisoner.  And while the Jailโs โGrievance Unitโ is required to store all grievances filed and 
25 
address the grievances, clearly that is not the case. 
26 
55.  This abuse and mistreatment also directly involves violations of existing jail policies 
27  and procedures, California statutes and California regulations.  Despite repeated complaints and even 
28  prior lawsuits, defendants and each of them failure and refusal to comply with policies and 
 
Page 17 of 24 
Mohrbacher v. Alameda County Sheriffโs Office. Second Amended Complaint, Case No. 3:18-cv-00050-JD 
 

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 72   Filed 04/12/18   Page 18 of 24
 
procedures, California statutes and California regulations, even after notification of resulting injuries 
1 
and harms, indicates callous and wanton and deliberate disregard for the safety, health and well being 
2 
of the women prisoners under their control, and clearly shows programmatic mistreatment and abuse 
3 
of women prisoners compared to men. 
4 
VI.  CLASS CLAIM 
5 
56.  Within the meaning of Rule 23, F.R.Civ. P., the Class of women prisoners, and 
6 
particularly the Subclass of pregnant prisoners, are both numerous and indeterminate, as women 
7 
come into and leave the Jail, so that joinder of all the claims already in view is clearly impracticable. 
8  (R. 23(a)(1).  In any given year, there are as many as 150 pregnant women in defendantsโ custody for 
9  some period of time. Joinder is inherently impractical because the number of unnamed, future class 
10  members who will be pregnant while in defendantsโ custody is unknown and unknowable, and, given 
the transient nature of the plaintiff population and the temporal limitations of pregnancy, their 
11 
identities will vary. Proposed class members are highly unlikely to file individual suits on their own 
12 
behalf given the practical, legal, monetary, and fear-based barriers that impede their access to counsel 
13 
to challenge defendantsโ abusive, coercive and punitive regime---not to mention defendantsโ active 
14 
measures preventing proposed class members from communicating amongst themselves and with 
15 
legal counsel.  
16 
57.  There are numerous common issues of both law and fact (R. 23(a)(2)), including but 
17 
not limited to the factual occurrence, vel non, of:  i) defendantsโ programmatic coercion for abortions, 
18  ii) abuse and mistreatment of pregnant prisoners which threaten the viability of fetuses and often 
19  terminate pregnancies, iii) prohibiting class members from communicating amongst themselves and 
20  with legal counsel, iv) failure to develop statutorily required care plans, v) discrimination against 
women in access to services, classes, ability to work, rights and privileges, and, vi) failure to comply 
21 
with state laws and regulations on meeting the needs of womenโs reproductive and menstrual needs.  
22 
Legal questions, regarding, e.g, the applicability of the various state statutes mentioned above, the 
23 
Constitutional standards to be applied in assessing the plaintiffsโ claims, and the like, will plainly be 
24 
the same with respect to all individual class members. 
25 
58.  The claims of the named plaintiffs are typical of the claims of members of the Plaintiff 
26 
Class, (R.23(a)(3)), and of members of the Subclass in particular, where all the pregnant women 
27 
prisoners, past, present and to come, complain in the same terms of the ill effects of defendantsโ 
28 
nonfeasance and maltreatment, and failure to follow the law.  The fact that different individuals 
 
Page 18 of 24

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 72   Filed 04/12/18   Page 19 of 24
 
suffered or may suffer different degrees of injury---obviously only certain ones suffered miscarriage, 
1 
for example---is not a bar to certification, particularly where, as here, the defendants have โacted or 
2 
refused to act on grounds generally applicable to the Class, thereby making appropriate final 
3 
injunctive relief;โ per Section (b)(2) of the Rule.  The underlying injuries flowing from practice and 
4 
policy are common to all pregnant women at Santa Rita to some serious, health-threatening degree, as 
5 
we have shown and will show.  
6 
59.  The named plaintiffs will---and are able to---fairly and adequately protect the interests 
7  of the Plaintiff Subclass, per Sub.(a)(4) of the Rule. The named plaintiffs have no interest at odds in 
8  any way with those of the Subclass, and each has affirmed to counsel her desire and willingness to 
9  pursue the matter on behalf of the other women who will come into Santa Rita with child. The 
attorneys representing the named plaintiffs are experienced civil rights practitioners, well able to 
10 
prosecute and carry on substantial federal constitutional litigation such as this, and with access to 
11 
additional help which is even now being assembled for the larger work.  The Undersigned represent 
12 
to the Court their determination to see this matter through---both as to the urgent immediate 
13 
pregnancy issues and the County defendantsโ broader gender/sex discrimination practices against 
14 
women---and, by the way, we hereby respectfully request that we be designated by the Court as 
15 
counsel for the Class of present and future women prisoners at Santa Rita, and the Subclass of those 
16 
among them who are pregnant. 
17  60.  From the pleadings, and particularly the many sworn affidavits submitted with 
18  plaintiffsโ pending renewed injunction motion, it is clear the defendants acted and now act and will 
19  act โon grounds generally applicable toโ the Subclass, in any case, thereby โmaking final injunctive 
relief appropriateโ to the class as a whole. The Plaintiff Class may therefore be properly certified 
20 
under R.23(b)(2).  Certainly, also it is patent that both factual and legal questions common to the 
21 
Subclass predominate here over individual concerns, so certification is also proper under Section 
22 
(b)(3). 
23 
61.  In sum, plaintiffs are entitled to have the Subclass of pregnant prisoners certified pro 
24 
tanto at the very least, or otherwise separately from the main class alleged herein, so that the 
25 
proceedings regarding emergency relief for all pregnant women who are in or may come into Santa 
26 
Rita can go forward without hindrance; and work on the claims of the Class as a Whole can abide 
27  further attention from the parties and the Court in the near future. 
28  //

groups of defendantsโ approaches to and practice in the care of pregnant prisoners, the 
28 
pattern and practice of defendantsโ non-feasance and maltreatment of pregnant prisoners,

3 
early compliance with the community treatment program law Penal Code ยง1170., and/or 
4 
any other feasible and available means and steps to get and keep pregnant women out of the 
5 
Santa Rita jail.

and new sanitary gloves;

PRELIMINARY STATEMENT 
15 
16  1.  This is a civil rights action in which the Plaintiffs, on behalf of themselves and a class 
17  of similarly situated female prisoners incarcerated in Santa Rita Jail, seek relief for Defendantsโ 
18  violations of Plaintiffsโ rights and privileges secured by the First, Fourth, Eighth and Fourteenth 
19  Amendments of the United States Constitution.  
20  2.  Defendant ALAMEDA COUNTY SHERIFFโS OFFICE (โSheriffโ) has implemented 
21  and enforced, and without the Courtโs intervention will continue to implement and enforce, a 
22  policy, practice, and/or custom of a multitude of policies and practices which discriminate against 
23  plaintiffs and those they seek to represent women, based upon their gender, in violation of the 
24  Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution, and Article 1, Section 7 of the California 
25  Constitution. 
26  3.  Without the Courtโs intervention, the Defendants in this action will continue to deny 
27  women prisoners at Santa Rita Jail, the same access as male prisoners to laundry, access and 
28  opportunities to exercise, access and opportunities for classes and programs, the same opportunities

Case 3:18-cv-00050-JD   Document 193   Filed 04/28/21   Page 3 of 40
 
1  as male prisoners for out of cell time, and the necessary protection against sexual harassment in 
2  violation of the Eighth Amendment, Fourteenth Amendment and Article 1, ยงยง7 and 17 of the 
3  California Constitution.   
4  4.  Defendants WELLPATH (formerly CALIFORNIA FORENSIC MEDICAL GROUP 
5  โWELLPATH/CFMGโ) and the ALAMEDA COUNTY SHERIFFโS OFFICE (โSheriffโ) have 
6  implemented and enforced, and without the Courtโs intervention will continue to implement and 
7  enforce, a policy, practice, and/or custom of denying pregnant women prisoners at Santa Rita Jail 
8  necessary and appropriate medical care, in violation of the Eighth Amendment, Fourteenth 
9  Amendment and Article 1, ยงยง7 and 17 of the California Constitution.   
10  5.  Defendants ARAMARK CORRECTIONAL SERVICES, LLC and the ALAMEDA 
11  COUNTY SHERIFFโS OFFICE have implemented and enforced, and without the Courtโs 
12  intervention will continue to implement and enforce, a policy, practice, and/or custom of denying 
13  pregnant women prisoners at Santa Rita Jail food that is adequate to maintain health in violation of 
14  the Fourteenth and Eighth Amendment and Article 1, ยงยง7 and 17 of the California Constitution.   
15  6.  This action seeks to end the barbaric conditions at SRJ regarding medical care and 
16  food.  These practices result in almost universal and inevitable miscarriages suffered by women 
17  who enter SRJ while pregnant.  These practices include coercion by ACSO and 
18  WELLPATH/CFMG staff to force inmates to have abortions.  These practices include the denial of 
19  materials necessary for personal hygiene with regard to inmatesโ menstrual cycle and reproductive 
20  systems.  The practices complained of herein are cruel and inhumane and violate the  most minimal 
21  standards of decency of a civilized society. 
22  7.  Plaintiffs bring this action for injunctive relief, and for monetary damages, 
23  individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated who have been and will be incarcerated at 
24  Santa Rita Jail, and to redress all Defendantsโ violations of their rights under the First, Fourth, 
25  Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution, and Article 1, ยงยง7 and 17 of 
26  the California Constitution.   
27 
28

2 
8.  This action is brought pursuant to the Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendments to the 
3 
United State Constitution, by way of the Civil Rights Acts, 42 U.S.C. ยงยง1981, 1983 et seq. and 
4 
1988.  
5 
9.  Jurisdiction is conferred upon this Court by 28 U.S.C. ยง1331 (claims arising under the 
6 
United States Constitution) and ยง1343 (claims brought to address deprivations, under color of state 
7 
authority, of rights privileges, and immunities secured by the United States Constitution), and, by 
8 
pendent jurisdiction, Secs. 52.1, and 50, of the California Civil Code and the aforementioned 
9 
statutory and constitutional provisions.   Plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief under 28 
10 
U.S.C. 1343, 2201, 2202 and 42 U.S.C. ยง1983. 
11 
Plaintiffs further invoke this Court's supplemental jurisdiction, pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1367,

11  52.  Over the past five years, Sheriff Ahearn has overseen an unprecedented increase in 
12  the salaries of Sheriffโs office personnel at Santa Rita Jail.  Salaries and benefits at SRJ have 
13  increased by $12.44 million dollars since 2013.  As a result, being a jail guard at SRJ is one of โ if

15  education can get.  A starting jail guards make approximately $100,000 per year in salary and

17  53.  That $12.4 million dollar salary increase, and the $1.7 million increase in overtime 
18  between 2013 and 2018 amounted to almost 50% of the Sherriffโs office SRJ budget increases over 
19  that period. 
20  54.  Over the same period, while remuneration for Sheriffโs office deputies and personnel 
21  at SRJ increased by nearly 18%, the SRJ jail population for whom the Sherriff was responsible, 
22  declined.   
23  55.  According to ACSO, the average daily population at SRJ was 3,431 inmates in June
